page.title: 09Industry. Cudworth's Mill
page.content: The mill is at least 200 years old. It is situated at the northern limits of the area and makes cotton fustian cloth for corduroy material, which is made into jackets and hats, and moleskin material, which is made into trousers. Walkers like this very much as it is warm and so tough that brambles and thorns will not go through to scratch legs. There are many looms in the weaving shed, not all of them are in use. It is very, very noisy. the fustian cloth is sent down the road to another mill to be 'finished'. The looms used to be powered by a steam engine called 'Mary' but are now driven by electricity. The mill is also called Baitings Mill. One meaning of 'Baitings' is 'resting place'. It is where packhorses used to rest on their journey.
